This may be suitable for the Caesars of Painting,

7. there are others who with great difficulty and labor,
sketch out or draw, hoping to gather
their subjects into an unbroken composition,
then draw clearly and precisely
what they have fixed fully in their minds,
on the primer with a thinned paint
that flows easily, or tracing neatly with Graphite
and wiping their work clean, leave it spotless.
right-middleBringing things together painstakingly, and then transferring them neatly, is advantageous in painting.

8. Yes, they make all things firmly and wisely,
surfaces as well as contours, by measuring,
without making a crooked line in error.
This goes well, and could not fail at all,
and is a great benefit in painting.
And for the painting to look good in all respects,
and not discolor, they set down
well mixed colors, each in its place
right-middlePutting each color in its place from the beginning, so as not to fade.

9. However, the Italians, no matter what they undertake
–whether painting on a wall, or on panel–
from elaborate sketches, with care, diligence,
and good study, they make cartoons,
which are the same size as their works in all parts,
they work the plaster with the ends of their brushes
or another sharp object that lends itself to it.
They go back over all the lines by pressing hard
right-middleItalians make cartoons, that is, papers as large as the work, neatly drawn, so that they can trace through them.

10. so that it transfers to the work
without breaks, and succeeds well.
For an Oil-painting, they first coat
the back of the cartoon with chalk or the like.
But on the wall, they press it while the plaster is still soft
by knowing (as I said) how to make
paintings in Fresco with an experienced hand;
which, in our Countries, is not done.

11. Nonetheless, the Florentine, who knew
how to sculpt as well as paint,
when he was asked to create his
Vatican Last Judgment in Oil,
for according to his account, this manner
of painting was the work of Women;
while working in Fresco he praised
as being an artful, Manly work.
right-middleHere is discussed Michelangelo, who called Oil-painting Women’s work and Fresco, Man’s work
